text: What Magic Box argues, is that the best outcomes for early-stage startups don't happen that way. You're never for sale. In fact, you have seduced a buyer. They see the fantasy, they fall in love.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about his Magic Box paradigm methodology for successfully selling startups. Jonathan is contrasting this approach with traditional M&A processes where companies put themselves up for sale and run a formal auction process. The Magic Box paradigm is a methodology that teaches founders to create acquisition opportunities by making buyers fall in love with a future vision rather than going through traditional sales processes.
text_ko: 매직 박스(Magic Box)가 말하는 건 초기 단계 스타트업에게 가장 좋은 결과는 그런 방식으로 오지 않는다는 거예요. 스타트업은 결코 '판매 대상'이 아니에요. 사실은 오히려 구매자를 매혹시킨 거예요. 그들은 그 판타지를 보고 사랑에 빠져요.
text_zh: Magic Box的观点是，对于早期创业公司来说，最好的结果不是这么来的。你从来不是待价而沽，实际上，你是在撩买家。他们看到了美好的愿景，然后就心动了。
text_es: Lo que plantea Magic Box es que los mejores resultados para startups en etapa temprana no suceden así. Nunca estás en venta. De hecho, has seducido a un comprador. Ven la fantasía, se enamoran.

text: To be a founder is a state of being, it's an attitude. To be a CEO is a craft. The more founders who can accept that those are two separate things and they're both equally important to build an ascendant startup, the better all of us will be.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Jonathan is wrapping up the conversation by sharing his core philosophy about the founder journey. He's making a critical distinction that many founders miss - being a founder (having the vision, courage, and drive to start something) is fundamentally different from being a CEO (learning the operational skills to run and scale a business). An ascendant startup is one that's rising or advancing successfully.
text_ko: 창업자(founder)는 어떤 정체성이자 태도예요. 반면 CEO(Chief Executive Officer)는 숙련이 필요한 역할이에요. 창업자들이 이 둘이 분명히 다른 것이라는 걸 받아들이고, 둘 다 성장하는 스타트업을 만들기 위해 똑같이 중요하다는 걸 인정할수록 우리 모두가 더 나아질 거예요.
text_zh: 创始人是一种状态，一种心态。而CEO是一门手艺活儿。越多创始人能够接受这是两码事，而且对于打造一个蒸蒸日上的初创公司来说都同样重要，那对我们大家都更有好处。
text_es: Ser fundador es una forma de ser, es una actitud. Ser CEO es un oficio que se aprende. Mientras más fundadores puedan aceptar que son dos cosas completamente distintas y que ambas son igual de importantes para construir una startup exitosa, mejor nos va a ir a todos.

text: Founder mode gets me angry. That article just got me hot. It really felt like an excuse. We were giving founders a permission to not learn the job. It's not manager mode is bad, it's the greatest CEOs know when to calibrate which one is needed.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about his thoughts on the popular 'founder mode' concept that had been circulating in the startup community. Founder mode refers to the idea that founders should stay deeply involved in details rather than delegating everything to managers. Jonathan is expressing his frustration with this concept because he believes it gives founders an excuse to avoid developing proper CEO skills and learning how to manage and scale organizations effectively.
text_ko: 창업자 모드(Founder mode) 얘기만 나오면 화가 나요. 그 기사를 보고 정말 열받았어요. 완전 변명 같았어요. 우리는 창업자들(founders)에게 일을 배우지 않아도 된다는 면죄부를 준 셈이었거든요. 매니저 모드(manager mode)가 나쁘다는 게 아니라, 최고의 CEO들(CEOs)은 언제 어떤 모드를 써야 할지, 어떻게 조절(calibrate)해야 할지 알고 있어요.
text_zh: 创始人模式这个说法真的让我很火大。那篇文章看得我直冒火。感觉就是在找借口嘛。我们这不是在给创始人开绿灯，让他们不用学怎么当老板吗。不是说管理者模式不好，而是最厉害的CEO都知道什么时候该用哪一套。
text_es: El "founder mode" me saca de quicio. Ese artículo me puso de malas. La verdad es que se sintió como una excusa barata. Les estábamos dando permiso a los fundadores para no aprender a hacer bien el trabajo. No es que el "manager mode" sea malo, es que los mejores CEOs saben cuándo calibrar cuál de los dos se necesita.

text: More companies die from suicide than homicide, and it's grim, but also if the two or three people in charge of the business can't get along, nothing else matters. It's all going to break apart.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Jonathan is explaining common failure modes for startups, categorizing them into four main areas. He's discussing what he calls 'founder's function' - the critical need for founding team members to work well together. By 'suicide vs homicide,' he means companies more often fail due to internal dysfunction (suicide) rather than external competitive forces (homicide). This is one of his frameworks for understanding why startups fail.
text_ko: 더 많은 회사가 외부의 공격으로 망하기보다 내부 갈등 때문에 스스로 무너져요. 참 암울하죠. 그런데 회사를 이끄는 두세 사람이 사이가 안 좋으면 다른 건 아무 소용 없어요. 결국 다 무너져 버려요.
text_zh: 更多公司是死于内斗而不是被外人搞垮的，这听起来很残酷，但确实如此。如果公司那几个当家的合不来，其他什么都白搭，早晚得散摊子。
text_es: Más empresas se van a pique por problemas internos que por la competencia, y aunque suena duro, si las dos o tres personas que manejan el negocio no se pueden ni ver, no importa nada más. Todo se va a ir al carajo.

text: If you keep doing what you're doing, you keep getting what you're getting. And for the ready, fire, aim folks who realize the weakness of that at scale, the way to counteract that, is to start with good planning.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Jonathan is discussing the 'ready, fire, aim' CEO type - one of his failure mode categories for founders who act impulsively without proper planning. He's explaining that while improvisational skills might help founders get their companies started, the same approach won't work for scaling the business. He's sharing advice from a former boss and explaining how founders can transition from reactive decision-making to more strategic planning.
text_ko: 계속 지금 하던 대로만 하면 지금 얻고 있는 것만 계속 얻게 돼요. 그리고 그 약점이 대규모(at scale)로 드러난다는 걸 아는 '준비-발사-조준(ready, fire, aim)' 방식의 사람들에게는 그걸 상쇄하는 방법이 바로 좋은 계획부터 시작하는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你一直按老办法做事，结果肯定还是老样子。对于那些习惯"准备，开火，瞄准"这种做法的人，当你意识到这样搞大了会有问题时，最好的解决办法就是一开始就做好规划。
text_es: Si sigues haciendo lo mismo de siempre, vas a seguir obteniendo los mismos resultados. Y para los que actúan primero y piensan después (ready, fire, aim) y se dan cuenta de que esto no funciona a gran escala, la manera de solucionarlo es empezar con una buena planificación desde el principio.

text: I trust founder intuition. If the founder says this business is still going to work, or this co-founder is the wrong person, or yes, it's time to sell, I'm in. We're just here to support them.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Lenny mentions that one of Jonathan's clients said the biggest lesson learned was to trust his intuition more. Jonathan is explaining his philosophy about supporting founders through difficult existential decisions. He believes that when founders get quiet and listen to their inner voice - what he calls founder intuition - they usually know the right answer. His role is not to give directive advice but to help founders access and trust their own judgment.
text_ko: 저는 창업자의 직감(founder intuition)을 믿어요. 창업자가 ‘이 사업은 아직 잘될 거예요’, ‘이 공동창업자(co-founder)는 맞지 않아요’, 또는 ‘이제 팔 때예요’라고 하면 저는 함께할게요. 우리는 그저 그들을 지원하러 온 거예요.
text_zh: 我相信创始人的直觉。如果创始人说这个生意还能做下去，或者说这个联合创始人不合适，或者说是时候卖掉了，我都支持。我们就是来给他们撑腰的。
text_es: Confío en la intuición del fundador. Si el fundador dice que este negocio todavía va a funcionar, o que este socio no es la persona indicada, o que sí, ya es hora de vender, yo me apunto. Nosotros estamos aquí simplemente para apoyarlos.

text: Early stage founders, and this is certainly more true for the first timers than the veterans, the first timers are like twenty-something year olds in a bar and they're being social for the first time in their lives, and anyone that makes eye contact with them is enough for them to say, I want to go on a date with you.
speaker: Jonathan Lowenhar
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about go-to-market strategy and where founders should focus their efforts. Jonathan is explaining the biggest mistake first-time founders make when defining their ideal customer profile (ICP). He's using a humorous analogy to describe how inexperienced founders often lack discrimination in choosing customers - they'll try to sell to anyone who shows interest rather than being selective about their target market.
text_ko: 초기 창업자들(early stage founders)은, 특히 처음 창업하는 사람들(first-timers)에게서 더 그렇습니다. 처음 창업하는 사람들은 마치 술집에 처음 나온 이십대 초반들처럼 사람들과 어울리는 게 처음이라서, 누군가 눈을 마주치기만 해도 '저 사람과 데이트하고 싶다'고 생각해요.
text_zh: 早期创业者，特别是那些第一次创业的，比有经验的老手更容易这样——就像二十多岁的年轻人第一次去酒吧社交，谁跟他们对个眼神，他们就想"我要跟你约会"。
text_es: Los fundadores en etapas tempranas, y esto es mucho más cierto para los primerizos que para los veteranos, los primerizos son como veinteañeros en un bar que están socializando por primera vez en sus vidas, y cualquiera que los mire a los ojos les basta para decir "quiero salir contigo".
